and possidere sibi and successoribus suis possint imperpetuum; Et ad omnia alia
faciendum, agendum and recipiendum prout and in eodem modo quo caeteri ligei
nostri personae habiles and capaces infra Regnun nostrum Angliae facere, agere
and recipere possint. Et ulterius de abundanti gratia nostra concessimus and
licentiam dedimus pro Nobis and haeredibus nostris praefato nunc Comiti,
executoribus and assignatis suis and eorum cuilibet, quod ipsi vel eorum
aliquis aut aliqui terras and tenementa cum pertinentiis ad valorem annuum
tresdecim librarum, sex solidorum and octo denariorum ultra omnia onera and
reprisas quae de Nobis non tenentur in Capite, dare and concedere possit and
possint Capellanis illis ejusdem Cantariae de Luffwyck and successoribus suis
praedictis habendum and tenendum hujusmodi terras and tenementa cum
pertinentiis eisdem Capellanis and successoribus suis imperpetuum juxta
ordinationem praedicti nunc Comitis seu executorum suorum vel eorum aliquorum
seu alicujus inde fiendam; Et eisdem Capellanis ejusdem Cantariae de Luffwyck,
quod ipsi and successores sui eadem terras and tenementa cum pertinentiis a
praefato nunc Comite, Executoribus seu assignatis suis seu eorum aliquibus aut
aliquo recipere possint, tenenda sibi and successoribus suis praedictis juxta
eandem ordinationem ut praemittitur fiendam sicut supradictum est imperpetuum,
tenore praesentium similiter licentiam dedimus specialem. Et quod praedicta
Cantaria de uno Capellano cum sic in dicta Ecclesia beatae Mariae de Plasshe
erecta, facta, fundata, creata and stabilita fuerit, Cantaria Edwardi Comitis
Wilts in Ecclesia beatae Mariae de Plasshe pro perpetuo nuncupetur; Et quod
Capellanus Cantariae illius and successores sui Capellani ejusdem Cantariae
sint bonum corpus corporatum in re and nomine habeantque successionem perpetuam
ac sint personae habiles and capaces in lege; Et quod Capellanus ejusdem
Cantariae and successores sui Capellani Cantariae illius per nomen and sub
nomine Capellani Comitis Wilts in Ecclesia beatae Mariae de Plasshe placitare
possit and implacitari, Necnon omnimodas actiones, sectas, querelas and causas
reales, personales and mixtas cujuscunque generis fuerint and naturae coram
quibuscunque Justiciariis, Judicibus spiritualibus and secularibus seu aliis
personis quibuscunque prosequi ac in eisdem respondere, and responderi, easque
defendere possint, ac per idem nomen, terras, tenementa and alias possessiones
and res quascunque habere, gaudere and possidere sibi and successoribus suis
possit imperpetuum, Et ad omnia alia faciendum, agendum and recipiendum prout
and in eodem modo quo caeteri ligei nostri personae habiles and capaces infra
Regnum Nostrum Angliae facere, agere and recipere possint. Et ulterius ex
abundanti gratia nostra concessimus and licentiam dedimus pro Nobis and
haeredibus nostris praefato nunc Comiti, executoribus and assignatis suis and
eorum cuilibet, quod ipsi vel eorum aliquis aut aliqui terras and tenementa cum
pertinentiis ad valorem annuum tresdecim Librarum and quatuor Solidorum ultra
omnia onera and reprisas, quae de Nobis non tenentur in Capite, dare and
concedere possit and possint eidem Capellano ejusdem Cantariae de Plasshe and
successoribus suis praedictis, Habendum and Tenendum hujusmodi terras and
tenementa cum pertinentiis eidem Capellano and successoribus suis imperpetuum
juxta ordinationem praedicti nunc Comitis seu executorum suorum vel eorum
aliquorum seu alicujus inde fiendam; Et eidem Capellano ejusdem Cantariae de
Plasshe, quod ipse and successores sui eadem terras and tenementa cum
pertinentiis a praefato nunc Comite, Executoribus seu assignatis suis seu eorum
aliquibus aut aliquo recipere possit and possint tenenda sibi and successoribus
suis praedictis juxta ordinationem ut praemittitur fiendam sicut supradictum
est imperpetuum, tenore praesentium similiter licetiam dedimus specialem,
absque molestatione, impedimento vel perturbatione nostri vel haeredum
nostrorum, Justiciariorum, Escaetorum, Vicecomitum, Coronatorum seu Ministrorum
vel haeredum nostrorum quorumcunque, and absque aliquo fine in Hanapario nostro
seu aliter ad opus nostrum seu haeredum nostrorum reddendo aut solvendo,
statuto de terris and tenementis ad manum mortuam non ponendis edito, aut eo
quod expressa mentio de vero valor annuo aut certitudine praemissorum seu
eorum alicujus sive de aliis donis aut concessionibus per Nos eidem nunc Comiti
antea factis, aut aliquo statuto, actu, ordinatione vel promissione in
contrarium factis, editis, ordinatis aut provisis, aut aliqua re, causa vel
materia quacunque in aliquo non obstante. In cujus rei testimonium has Literas
nostras fieri fecimus Patentes.

Test meipso apud Westmonasterium vicesimo primo die Novembris Anno Regni
nostri quarto decimo. Kelet. Per breve de privato Sigillo and de data praedicta
auctoritate Parliamenti pro viginti Martis solutis in Hanapario.

Carta Johannae Vicecomitissae Lisle and aliorum.
OMnibus Christi fidelibus ad quos hoc praesens Scriptum pervenerit, Johanna
Vicecomitissa Lisle, Johannes Vicecomes Lisle, Thomas Gray Armiger, Thomas
Kevell serviens Domini Regis ad legem, Edwardus Hungerford Armiger, Humfridus
Conyngesby, Thomas Frowyk, Johannes Titchbourne, Johannes Smyth, Johannes
Gardyner, Thomas Byall and Thomas Heywoode
salutem in Domino sempiternam.
Cum Robertus Wittelbury Armiger, Thomas Mountegu and Johannes Freeman per
Cartam suam indentatam cujus data est tertio die mensis Julii Anno Regni Regis
Henrici Septimi nono, dimiserint, feoffaverint, liberaverint and eadem Carta
sua confirmaverint Edwardo Comiti Wilts and Margaretae uxori suae per nomen
Margaretae Gray filiae Edwardi nuper Vicecomitis Lisle and Elizabethae uxoris
ejus, ac Nobis praefatae Johannae Vicecomitissae Lisle, Thomae Gray Armigero,
Thomae Kevell servienti Domini Regis ad legem, Edwardo Hungerford Armigero,
Humfrido Conyngesby, Thomae Frowyk, Johanni Titchbourne, Johanni Smyth, Johanni
Gardyner, Thomae Byall and Thomae Heywoode Maneria sua de Waterhale, Brafeld,
Pollycote, Wanden, Emberton and Wolston magna cum pertinentiis in Comitatu
Buckinghamiae, ac Manerium suum de Chalton cum pertinentiis in Comitatu
Bedfordiae, ac etiam Maneria sua de Suttons, Pyggesland, Tracyes and Stamford
Ryvers cum pertinentiis in Comitatu Essexiae, Necnon omnia terras and
tenementa, redditus, reversiones and servitia cum suis pertinentiis in
Comitatibus praedictis quae inter alia praefatus Robertus Wittelbury Armiger,
Willielmus Marbury Armiger, Thomas Mountegu and Johannes Freeman ac Willielmus
Feld Clericus and Robertus Bayston Clericus nuper habuerunt sibi and haeredibus
suis ex dono and feoffamento dicti Comitis, prout per quandam Cartam sibi inde
confectam before apparet; qui quidem Willielmus Feld and Robertus Bayston
totum jus suum in maneriis, terris and tenementis praedictis ac caeteris
praemissis praefatis Roberto Wittelbury, Willelmo Marbury, Thomae Mountegu and
Johanni Freeman remiserunt and relaxaverunt, prout per eorum scriptum inde sibi
confectum similiter apparet: Habendum and tenendum praedicta Maneria, terras
and tenementa, redditus, reversiones and servitia cum pertinentiis praefatis
Comiti and Margaretae uxori suae, ac Nobis praesatae Johannae, Johanni
Vicecomiti Lisle, Thomae Gray, Thomae Kevell, Edwardo Hungerford, Humfrido
Conyngesby, Thomae Frowyk, Johanni Titchbourne, Johanni Smyth, Johanni
Gardyner, Thomae Byall and Thomae Heywoode pro termino vitae ejusdem Margaretae
remanere inde praefato Comiti, haeredibus and assignatis ejusdem Comitis
imperpetuum, prout in eadem carta before liquet: Noveritis Nos praefatos
Johannam Vicecomitissam Lisle, Johannem Vicecomitem Lisle, Thomam Gray, Thomam
Kevell, Edwardum Hungerford, Humfridum Conyngesby, Thomam Frowyk, Johannem
Titchbourne, Johannem Smyth, Johannem Gardyner, Thomam Byall and Thomam
Heywoode remisisse, relaxasse and omnino pro Nobis and haeredibus nostris
imperpetuum quietum clamasse praefato Edwardo Comiti Wilts and Margaretae uxori
suae totum jus, titulum, clameum, demaundam and interesse nostra de and in
omnibus praedictis Maneriis de Waterhall, Brafeld, Pollycote, Wanden, Emberton
and Wolston magna cum pertinentiis in Comitatu Buckinghamiae, ac Manerio de
Chalton cum pertinentiis in Comitatu Bedfordiae, ac etiam Maneriis de Suttons,
Pyggesland, Tracyes, and Stamford Ryvers cum pertinentiis in Comitatu Essexiae;
Necnon de omnibus terris, tenementis, redditibus, reversionibus cum suis
pertinentiis in Comitatibus praedictis: Ita quod nec Nos praefati Johanna
Vicecomitissa Lisle, Johannes Vicecomes Lisle, Thomas Gray, Thomas Kevell,
Edwardus Hungerford, Humfridus Conyngesby, Thomas Frowyk, Johannes Titchbourne,
Johannes Smyth, Johannes Gardyner, Thomas Byall, and Thomas Heywoode nec
haeredes nostri, nec aliquis alius pro Nobis seu nomine nostro aliquid juris
vel clamei in praedictis Maneriis, terris, tenementis, redditibus,
reversionibus praedictis and caeteris praemissis cum omnibus suis pertinentiis
de caetero exigere seu vendicare poterimus in futuro, set ab omni action
juris, clamei seu aliquid inde petendi sumus exclusi imperpetuum per praesentes.

In cujus rei testimonium Sigilla nostra apposuimus....... die mensis.......
Anno Regni Regis Henrici Septimi post Conquestum Angliae quarto decimo.
Ultima Voluntas Edwardi Comitis Wilts.
IN the name of God Amen. The two and twentieth day of March in the year of
our Lord one thousand four hundred nynety and eight: I Edward Earl of
Wyltshire of hole mind and good memory bequeth my soul to Almighty God my
Creator and Savior, to our Lady Seint Marie, and to all the holy company of
Hevyn, and my body to be beryed within the Church of Seint Peter in Luffwycke
in our Lady I Will, by me Graundfader Green, and will mine Executors make a
convenient Tomb to be made for me. Item, I will that the last Will of my Lord
my Fader, my Lady my Mother, and my Graundfader Green be performed. Item, I
will that where Robert Wittelbury, William Merbury Esquires, William Feld
Clarke, Robert Bayston Clarke, Thomas Mountegu and John Freeman been seasid of
the Manors of Buckworth, Comberton, Raundes, Ryngsted, Irtlingborough,
Haringworth and Hardewyke in the Counties of Huntingdon, Cambridge and
Northampton, and of oder Lands and Tenements, Woods, Meadows and Pastures in
Buckworth, Comberton, Raundes, Rygsted, Irtlingborough, Hardewycke and
Haringworth in the Counties aforesaid, in there Demesne as of Fee to the use of
me and mine heirs; and whereas Margaret my Wife, John Viscounte Lisle and
other Cofeffes been seasid of the Manors of Stamford Ryvers, Piggesland,
Tracyes and Suttons in the County of Essex, and of the Manors of Newington,
Blosmavyle and Pollicote in the County of Bucks, and of certain Lands and
tenements, woods, meadows and pastures belongyng and appartaynyng unto the
seid Manors in their demesne, as of Fee to the use of me and of Margaret my
wife for term of hur life; for certain causes and considerations I will that
the seid Robert Wittelbury, William Merbury, William Feld Clarke, Robert
Bayston Clarke, Thomas Mountagu and John Freeman, that the foreseid Robert
Wittelbury and all the seid Cofeoffes abovenamed, and all other Feoffes in the
seid Manors, Lands and tenements, woods, meadows and pastures shall be and
stand Feoffes in all the seid Manors, Londs and tenements, meadows and pastures
in Buckworth, Comberton, Raundes, Ringsted, Irtlingborough, Hardwyke and
Haringworth to the intent following; That is to sey, That I will the seid
Margaret my wife shall have and enjoy all the profits and revenues of the seid
Manors of Buckworth, Comberton, Ringsted, Irtlingborough, Hardwyck and
Haringworth with their appurtynances for term of her life, with this
condition, that she make no title, cleyme nor interesse in noon of the Manors
of Stamford Ryvers, Pyggesland, Tracyes, Suttons, Newenton, Blosmavile and
Policote, the which I will shall descend unto my Lord of Buckingham and his
heirs, and I beseech my seid Lord to suffer my wife to have the Manors of
Newynton, Blosmavile, for term of her life, and to be good Lord unto her and
my Servaunts. Item, I will that all such Annuities and Fees as be granted by
Deed or Patentes by my Lord my Fader, my Lady my Mother, my Grandfader Green
and me, be had ferme and stable for term of their life, without let or
interruption. Item, I will that my Feoffes that now been, or hereafter shall
be, suffer William Merbury and Thomas Mountegu to take and receyve the revenues
and profits of my Lands, Tenements, Woods, Meadows and Pastures in Luffewicke
and Islip unto they be content, and saved harmless against the King for the
Det of One hundred and twenty nine Pounds, one Shilling and four Pence,
wherefore they be bound by obligation to Sir Reynold Bray, and to Sir Thomas
Lovel to pay and content before the Fest of Christmas next following, to the
Kings use for the lycense of the mortisment of two Chauntries in Plasshe and
Luffwick, and after that done, and the said William and Thomas saved harmless
as I have indentyd with them, the which will appear, and furthermore suertie
for ready payment, I will the said William Merbury and Thomas Mountegu have in
their keeping my two Flaggons, two gylte Potts, six Bollys gylt with Covers and
other Plate to make Chevysaunce to pay the King, and they so savyd harmless,
then I will my Feoffes stand and be Feoffes unto the perfourment of this my
last Will, as well of these as of other; and I will the seid my Executours to
sell my woods at Langhyll, Farthyngshawe, Hotland, Bullaks and Colys wood,
and all my woods growing, being and belongyng to Bakenho, Grymsbury, Malberne,
or any oder place such as was purchased of William Eton by my Lord my Fader.
Item, I will my Executours have all my moveable Goods unbequeathed, as well
Juels, Plate, Stuff to pay my Detts, and to perform this my last Will. Item,
I will my Lord of Buckingham have all my Stuff that I left in his place in
Bredstrede except my Robys of Astate, and Robys of Parliament, the which Robys
of Astate I will they be gevyn to Churches whereas I was Patron, there as most
need is by the discretion of mine Executours; and the other Robys and Furris to
be sold, and the money takyn to pay my Detts, and perform my Will. Item, I
will my Lord and Cossen of Shrewsbury have my Collar of the Kings Livery, and
my Unkyll Wittelbury oon of my Bollys of Silver with a Cover that I bought
last; mine Aunte his Wife to have a plain stonding cup of Silver gylt that is
used to be carried with me. Item, I will the Church of Luffwyck have my Trapper
of Cloth of Gold, and my auter Clothes of Tawney Damask. Item, I will the
Church of Newenton have the outside of my Goune of Crymson Velvet to make a
Cope; and I will the Church of Graston have the lynyng of black Damask in the
same to make a Vestyment and a Cope. Item, I will that Margret my wife have as
much Plate as I had with her in marriage, my Fether-bed in the Chapel Chamber,
the Tester, Sealer and Counterpoynt of the same, Carpets of the same, my two
great Carpets, two Cushyns of tawny Damask, two Payr of fine Shetes and three
Payr of other Shetes, my fine cloth of Diaper, my Bed of Cloth of Gold and
Velvet that was in London, and my Pelows of the best, so that my Detts may be
content with other my Goods and revenues of my Lands, and with that she leve
and take not the third part of my Goods, but suffer mine Executours to have
them at their liberty to perform my will. Item, I will that every Gentilman
and Gentilwoman have forty shillings, every Yeoman twenty shillings, and every
Grome ten shillings. Item, I will that my howsold be kept thirty days after my
decesse, if there be whereof so to do. Item, I will that Mr. William Feld
Master of the Collage of Foderinghay have oon of my bollys of Silver that I
bought last. Item, I will that my Detts and my revenues of my Lands be
receyved by mine Executours to pay my Detts and perform my will. Item, I will
that my poor Kin and Servaunts have and be relyved before any other by the
discretion of mine Executours. Item, I will that my Executours give and grant
a annuite of forty Shillings by Deed, out of my Lands that my Lord my Fader
purchased of William Eton in Bedfordshire unto my welbeloved Servaunt Edward
Bruet, and the kepeing of my Manor and Conynger of Drayton, for term of his
life. Item, I will that all my Juells, Plate and other stuff unbequethed be
sold by mine Excutours to perform this my last Will. Item, I will that all my
Brigandyrs and Harnes be distributed among my Yomen and Gromes, after the
discretion of my Executours. And of this my present last Will I make my
Executors, my entireley belovid Uncle Robert Wittelbury, Mr. William Feld
Master of the Collage of Fotheringhay, William Merbury, Thomas Mountegu and
John Blake. Item, I desire and pray my good Lord and Cossen the Earl of
Shrewsbury to be surveyer of this my last Will, and to be good Lord unto my
wife and pore servauntes, as my singular trust is in him; And I will that every
of mine Executours, that will minister this my last Will, to have six Pounds,
thirteen Shillinges and four Pence. In witness whereof I the said Earl have
put to my Seal.

Item, I will that my Feoffes grant by Deed or Patent a Annuite unto my right
welbeloved Servaunt Philip Frost, of fifty three Shillings four Pence, for
term of his life, out of my Lands and Tenements in Luffwycke, for the good
and long service that he has done unto me. Item, I will that my Lands and
Tenements that I purchased in Luffwycke, of the wife of William Chamber, called
Cottingham's Tenement and Ridayes Close with the appurtenances, and the Lands
and Tenements in the same Town, that I purchased of the heirs of Oliver
Sutton, be sold to pay my Detts, and to perform this my last Will. Item, That
my welbeloved Servaunt Robert Wilkinson, have forty Shillings out of my Lands
in Islip, for term of his life.

The Tomb of Edward Stafford Earl of Wiltsheire, and Lord of Drayton Extant
in S.t Peter's Church in Luffwick.
tomb of Edward Stafford, 2nd earl of Wiltshire
Copia Statutorum Cantariae Edwardi Comitis Wilts de Villa Luffwycke.
UNiversis Sanctae matris Ecclesiae filiis ad quos praesentes Literae
pervenerint, Robertus Wittelbury Armiger, Willielmus Marbury Armiger, and
Thomas Mountagu Gentilman Executores testamenti and ultimae Voluntatis nobilis
memoriae Edwardi Stafford nuper Comitis Wiltshyre defuncti, Salutem in Domino
sempiternam. Ad Universitatis vestrae notitiam deducimus, ac tenore praesentium
volumus deduci quod praefatus nobilis Dominus Edwardus nuper Comes Wiltshyre
duas Cantarias perpetuas, unam videlicet Cantariam perpetuam de duobus
Capellanis divina in Ecclesia parochiali de Luffwycke in Comitatu
Northamptoniae Lincolniensis Dioceseos, and aliam Cantariam perpetuam de uno
Capellano in Ecclesia beatae Mariae de Plassey in Comitatu Essexiae pro salubri
statu Domini nostri Regis Henrici Septimi moderni and Dominae Elizabethae
Reginae Angliae praefatique Edwardi Comitis Wiltshyre dum viverent, and pro
animabus ipsorum postquam ab hac luce subtracti fuerint, and pro animabus
certarum aliarum personarum per ipsum Comitem nominatarum and inferius
expressatarum and omnium fidelium defunctorum juxta ordinationem in ea part
faciendam celebraturis, facere, fundare, creare, erigere and stabilire voluit,
intendebat, and ad hoc se disposuit; Atque certas Literas Regias Patentes a
praefato serenissimo Domino nostro Rege Henrico Septimo concessas, continentes
inter alia, licentiam and consensum ipsius Domini nostri Regis ad hujusmodi
Cantarias sub certis modo and forma in ipsis Literis Regiis (ad quas Nos
Executores praedicti referimus, and eas quatenus expedit hic haberi volumus)
pro insertis before expressatis faciendas, erigendas, fundandas and
stabiliendas eidem Domino Edwardo Comiti and Executoribus suis concedi and
haberi etiam procuravit and obtinuit: Idem tamen nobilis vir Edwardus Comes
Wiltshyre in hujusmodi suo pio and laudabili proposito morte naturali
praeventus ad erectionem and fundationem dictarum Cantariarum nullatenus
processit, sicque hujusmodi erectionem and fundationem Nobis Executoribus suis
praedictis reliquit and omnino dimisit. Nos igitur Robertus Wittelbury,
Willielmus Marbury and Thomas Mountagu Executores praedicti piam intentionem
and laudabile propositum dicti Comitis defuncti multipliciter in Domino
commendantes, attendentesque quod fundationes and erectiones dictarum
Cantariarum in augmentum cultus divini ac salutem animarum tam ipsius Comitis
defuncti quam parentum and amicorum suorum ac aliorum omnium Christi dilectorum
defunctorum tendere omnino videntur; Cupientes propterea quantum cum Deo
possumus id quod ipse nobilis vir in vita sua salubriter fieri proposuit post
mortem suam juxta ipsius ultimam Voluntatem Nobis in ea part per eundem
saepius declaratam stabilire and perficere, ad fundationem, erectionem,
creationem and stabilimentum dictae Cantariae perpetuae in praefata parochiali
Ecclesia de Luffwycke Lincolniensis Dioceseos juxta omnem vim formam and
effectum licentiae regiae dicto Comiti and Executoribus suis in hac part
concessae, and prout ipse Comes in vita sua desuper express fieri voluerit,
procedimus in hunc modum. Imprimis Nos Robertus Wittelbury, Willielmus Marbury
and Thomas Mountagu Executores testamenti and ultimae Voluntatis nobilis
memoriae Domini Edwardi Stafford nuper Comitis Wiltshyre defuncti, ad laudem
and honorem omnipotentis Dei ac beatissimae Virginis Mariae matris suae
gloriosae, ac ad salutem animarum dicti Comitis and aliorum infra nominatorum,
deque licentia and consensu metuendissimi Domini nostri Regis Henrici Septimi
moderni concurrentibus, etiam consensu and assensu omnium and singulorum quorum
interest in hac part, facimus, creamus, erigimus and fundamus nomine
Executorio praefati nobilis Comitis defuncti, ac vice, voluntate and mandato
ejusdem unam perpetuam Cantariam duorum Capellanorum secularium in Ecclesia
parochiali Sancti Petri de Luffwycke Lincolniensis Dioceseos divina in eadem
Ecclesia ad altar Sancti Petri ibidem pro salubri statu praefati Domini nostri
Regis Angliae ac praeclarissimae Dominae Dominae Elizabethae Reginae Angliae
modernae nostrumque Executorum praenominatorum dum vixerimus, ac pro animabus
eorundem Domini nostri Regis and Reginae postquam ab hac luce subtracti
fuerint, ac pro anima dicti Domini Edwardi Stafford nuper Comitis Wiltshyre and
animabus Johannis Stafford nuper Comitis Wiltshyre and Constanciae uxoris suae
parentum ipsius Domini Edwardi nuper Comitis, ac pro animabus Henrici Green
Armigeri and Margaretae uxoris suae parentum ipsius Constanciae, pro animabus
Johannis Wittelbury Armigeri, Humfridi Stafford nuper Ducis Buckinghamiae,
Humfridi Stafford nuper Comitis Stafford, Henrici Green Militis and Dominae
Amabilae uxoris suae, Henrici Green Militis and Matildis uxoris suae, Johannis
Green Armigeri and Margaretae uxoris suae, Radulphi Green and Dominae
Catharinae uxoris suae, Roberti Ross Militis and Dominae Johannae uxoris suae,
Johannis Marbury and Elianorae uxoris suae, Oliveri Sutton and Graciae uxoris
suae, ac pro animabus nostrum praefatorum Roberti Wittelbury and Annae uxoris
meae, Willielmi Marbury and Annae uxoris meae, Thomae Mountagu and Mariae
uxoris meae, Necnon pro animabus parentum and omnium amicorum and benefactorum
praefati Henrici Green Armigeri and omnium fidelium defunctorum singulis
diebus juxta ordinationem nostram inferius descriptam perpetuo celebratorum.
Ita tamen quod iidem Capellani pro tempore quo in eadem Cantaria intitulati
fuerint, nullum beneficium Ecclesiasticum alibi quovismodo habeant aut
occupent, sed eidem Cantariae tantum deserviant and intendant, ac in eadem
personaliter and continuo juxta modum inferius specificatum resideant debite
cum effectu. Quam quidem Cantariam, perpetuam Cantariam Edwardi nuper Comitis
Wiltshyre in Ecclesia parochiali Sancti Petri de Luffwycke, pro perpetuo
nuncupari and esse volumus, fundamus and ordinamus per praesentes. Volumus
quoque insuper, fundamus and ordimus vice, nomine and voluntate dicti Domini
Edwardi Stafford nuper Comitis Wiltshyre, etiam ex licentia dicti Domini nostri
Regis, quod Capellani praedicti and successores sui Capellani dictae Cantariae
sint corpus unum incorporatum in re and nomine, habeantque successionem
perpetuam, and sint personae habiles and capaces in lege; Et quod ipsi
Capellani and eorum successores in eadem Cantaria pro nomine and sub nomine
Capellanorum Comitis Wiltshyre, in Ecclesia parochiali Sancti Petri de
Luffwycke possint-placitare and placitari, Necnon omnimodas actiones, sectas,
querelas and causas reales, personales and mixtas, cujuscunque generis fuerint
and naturae, coram quibuscunque Justiciariis, Judicibus spiritualibus and
secularibus seu aliis personis prosequi, and in eisdem respondere ac agere and
defendere; Ac per idem nomen, terras and tenementa ac alias possessiones and
res quascunque perquirere, habere, gaudere, possidere possint sibi and
successoribus suis imperpetuum; Et ad omnia alia facienda agenda and recipienda
prout and in eodem modo sicut caeteri ligei Domini nostri Regis personae
habiles and capaces infra regnum Angliae facere, agere and recipere possint
juxta and secundum vim, formam, tenorem and effectum literarum patentium Domini
nostri Regis praedicti desuper factarum and concessarum. Volumus quoque
insuper, statuimus and ordinamus Nos Executores supranominati, quod Capellani
dictae Cantariae praesententur and uterque ipsorum praesentetur per Nos
Executores praedictos, quamdiu aliquis nostrum vixerit, Domino Episcopo
Lincolniensi sede plena, vel sede vacant Officiali Lincolniensi qui pro
tempore fuerit, and per eundem Dominum Episcopum vel Officialem admittantur and
instituantur, ac per Rectorem Ecclesiae parochialis de Luffwycke si praesens
fuerit, vel eo absente per ejus Vicegerentem in possessionem dictae Cantariae
ad mandatum dicti Domini Episcopi inducantur; Et post mortem nostram and
cujuslibet nostrum praesentatio hujusmodi Capellanorum and eorum utriusque in
omni vacationis vice pertineat magistro Roberto Barnard magistro Collegii de
Foderinghay and successoribus suis imperpetuum; Ita quod ipse magister infra
mensem immediate sequentem postquam sibi de vacatione alicujus partis dictae
Cantariae constiterit, aliquem Capellanum honestum and idoneum alibi non
beneficiatum praefato Domino Episcopo Lincolniensi sede plena, vel Officiali
Lincolniensi sede Episcopali vacant, literatorie and cum effectu praesentet.
Et si sic praesentare ultra dictum mensem distulerit, tunc praesentatio ad
istam partem Cantariae sic vacantem pro illa vacationis vice pertineat ad
Dominum Abbatem Monasterii Sancti Petri de Burgo Lincolniensis Dioceseos qui
pro tempore fuerit; Ita tamen quod idem Dominus Abbas infra mensem postquam
constiterit eidem quod jus praesentandi sibi ut praefertur devolutum fuerit,
reale and literatorie praesentet ad illam partem dictae Cantariae tunc vacantem
honestum and idoneum Capellanum alibi non beneficiatum Domino Episcopo
Lincolniensi sede plena, seu sede Episcopali vacant Officiali Lincolniensi qui
pro tempore fuerit. Et si dictus Dominus Abbas ultra dictum mensem sic
praesentare distulerit seu omiserit, quod tunc been liceat Domino Episcopo
Lincolniensi pro tempore existenti sede plena, seu Officiali Lincolniensi sede
vacant, dictam Cantariam sic tunc vacantem alicui Capellano idoneo alibi non
beneficiato pro illa vacationis vice confer and ipsum admittere and
instituere Canonice in eadem. Et si idem Dominus Episcopus plena, vel Dominus
Officialis Lincolniensis Dioceseos sede vacant non contulerit infra mensem
postquam notitiam habuerit de vacatione alicujus partis dictae Cantariae and de
devolutione juris patronatus ad eandem, quod tunc praesentatio ad illam partem
Cantariae sic vacantem redeat ad Magistrum dicti Collegii de Foderinghay, Et
istum cursum sive ordinem praesentandi ad dictam Cantariam and providendi eidem
volumus and ordinamus sub praemissis modo and forma quotiescunque, quandocunque
and quomodocunque dictam Cantariam aut aliquam partem ejusdem post mortem
nostrum Executorum praedictorum and cujuslibet nostrum vacare contigerit,
perpetuis futuris temporibus observari. Volumus insuper and pro perpetuo
ordinamus Nos Executores supranominati, quod uterque dictorum Capellanorum
praefatae Cantariae tempore admissionis suae ad eandem, cumque inducatur in
realem possessionem ejusdem, juramentum praestet corporale tactis sacrosanctis
Evangeliis coram Nobis Executoribus praedictis aut aliquo nostrum diutius
vivente, ac post mortem cujuslibet nostrum coram magistro Collegii de
Foderinghay pro tempore existente, quod in praefata Cantaria quamdiu in eadem
intitulatus fuerit, continuo residebit and personaliter deserviet eidem, ac
fundationem and ordinationem ejusdem Cantariae and omnia in eis contenta pro
viribus and posse suis inviolabiliter observabit quatenus ad ipsam Cantariam
pertineat. Volumus insuper and ordinamus quod non liceat alicui Capellanorum
dictae Cantariae se absentare ab eadem ultra triginta dies in anno simul vel
interpolatis vicibus numerandos sive capiendos; Ita tamen quod ambo Capellani
nunquam sint simul absentes, sed tempore absentiae unius Capellanorum alter
Capellanus sit praesens in dicta Cantaria, and eidem debite deserviat. Et si
quis dictorum Capellanorum secum non residendo in dicta Cantaria contra
effectum and tenorem ordinationis ejusdem aut de habendo una cum eadem Cantaria
aliud beneficium Ecclesiasticum quodcunque sive qualitercunque fuerit,
dispensari procuraverit seu obtinuerit, ipso facto eundem Capellanum dicta
Cantaria privatum and ab eadem extunc pro perpetuo amotum esse ordinamus,
volumus and statuimus per praesentes, and in eo casu alius Capellanus ideoneus
loco ipsius Capellani sic amoti intituletur in dicta Cantaria juxta modum and
formam superius annotatum. Ordinamus insuper, volumus and statuimus, quod
nomina dicti Domini nostri Henrici Regis Angliae Septimi, Dominae Elizabethae
Reginae Angliae modernae, ac nomina and cognomina praefati Domini Edwardi
Stafford nuper Comitis Wiltshyre praecipui fundatoris hujus Cantariae,
nostrumque Executorum praenominatorum, Necnon caeterorum omnium and singulorum
superius in primo statuo sive prima part hujus ordinationis nominatim and
specifice expressatorum, in una tabula decenti and honesta inscribantur and
intitulentur, Et quod ipsa tabula ponatur and collocetur super Altar ad quod
dicta Cantaria infra dictam parochialem Ecclesiam fundatur, ad effectum, ut
Capellani ejusdem Cantariae perpetuis futuris temporibus in fingulis missis
suis ibidem celebrandis Dominum devote and specialiter deprecentur pro felici
statu dictorum Domini nostri Regis moderni and Dominae nostrae Reginae
modernae, ac pro bono statu nostrum Executorum supranominatorum quamdiu aliquis
nostrum vixerit, ac pro animabus ipsorum Domini nostri Regis and Reginae ac
animabus nostrum Executorum praedictorum postquam ab hac luce subtracti
fuerimus, necnon animabus omnium and singulorum superius nominatorum and omnium
fidelium defunctorum, ac ipsos in specie and nominatim in missis hujusmodi
habeant devote recommendatos. Ordinamus insuper, volumus and statuimus, quod
neuter Capellanorum praedictorum aliqua terras seu tenementa aut alias
possessiones, seu alia bona mobilia seu immobilia quae dictae Cantariae
pertinent aut imposterum quovismodo pertinebunt, alienet, vendat seu
impignoret, Et si sic fecerit, ipsum in vigniti solidis eidem Cantariae ad opus
reparationis ornamentorum ejusdem convertendos and persolvendos ipso facto
ordinamus condemnari. Et ad solutionem hujusmodi viginti solidorum totiens
quotiens sic fecerit, and ad restitutionem bonorum hujusmodi sic alienatorum,
venditorum seu impignoratorum, seu saltem competentem satisfactionem pro
eisdem, ad prosecutionem seu sectam alterius Capellani sui vel magistri
Collegii de Foderinghay pro tempore existentis modo and forma quibus celerius
and efficacius fieri possit, cogatur and compellatur; alioquin si sic solvere,
restituere seu satisfacere recusaverit seu indebite distulerit, ipsum sic
alienantem, vendentem seu impignorantem propter alienationem, venditionem seu
impignorationem hujusmodi a dicta Cantaria ipso facto ordinamus esse amotum,
and in loco illius sic amoti volumus and ordinamus alium Capellanum in dicta
Cantaria Canonice intitulari juxta formam superius annotatam. Volumus insuper,
statuimus and ordinamus, quod dicti Capellani and eorum successores in vim
juramenti per eos and eorum quemlibet in admissione sua ad dictam Cantariam
praestiti and praestandi, been, honest and pacifice mutuo se habeant atque
gerant, and quod neuter ipsorum Capellanorum cum altero Capellano socio suo
verbosus sit vel contumeliosus, neque rixas aut verba opprobriosa seu
contumeliosa quoquomodo inter se seminaverit. Volumus insuper, statuimus and
ordinamus Nos Executores supranominati, quod praemissa omnia and singula per
Nos ut praefertur statuta and ordinata, caeteraque imposterum statuenda and
ordinanda quaecunque per dictos duos Capellanos eorumque successores quoscunque
praefatae Cantariae Capellanos, perpetuis futuris temporibus plene, fideliter
and inviolabiliter observentur, quatenus facultates possessionum and bonorum
dictae Cantariae sufficere valiant in hac part; facultatem tamen and
potestatem praemissa omnia and singula per Nos ut praemittitur statuta and
ordinata ac imposterum statuenda and ordinanda interpretandi and declarandi,
eisdemque addendi ac ea corrigendi, emendandi and reformandi, Nobis
Executoribus antedictis and duobus nostrum reservamus per praesentes. In cujus
rei Testimonium Sigilla nostra praesentibus apposuimus. Dat' primo die mensis
Martii, Anno Domini Milesimo quingentesimo primo, and Anno Regni Regis dicti
Domini nostri Henrici Septimi post Conquestum Angliae decimo septimo.

ET Nos Willielmus permissione divina Lincolniensis Episcopus, dictae Cantariae
erectionem, fundationem and ordinationem superius expressatas vidimus and
inspeximus; Et quia Nobis evidenter constat hujusmodi Cantariae fundationem and
ordinationem tendere in divini cultus augmentum, ac salutem animarum omnium
fidelium defunctorum, and praesertim nobilis Domini Edwardi Stafford nuper
Comitis Wiltshyre and aliarum Nobilium personarum in dicta fundatione
specialiter expressarum, Idcirco ejusdem Cantariae fundationem, ordinationem
and erectionem supra specificatam, ac omnia and singula in eis statuta,
ordinata and contenta, auctoritate nostra ordinaria and pontificiali pro Nobis
and successoribus nostris quantum in Nobis est, and ad forum spectat
Ecclesiasticum, ex certa scientia ac ad omnem juris effectum qui inde sequi
poterit quomodolibet seu debebit in futurum, ratificamus, approbamus and
confirmamus, ac vires perpetuae firmitatis obtinere volumus. In quorum
testimonium praemissorum Sigillum nostrum praesentibus est appensum.

Dat' in Pallatio nostro Lincolniensi vicesimo octavo die mensis Martii, Anno
Domini Milesimo quingentesimo secundo and nostrae translationis anno septimo.
Depositions of Robert Merbury and others.
Facta fuit sequens examinatio secret and sigillatim testium subscriptorum
octavo die Februarii, Anno Regni Regis Henrici Octavi secundo, in quadam alta
Camera Domus solite residentiae venerabilis viri Magistri Johannis Young,
Magistri sive Custodis Rotulorum Cancellariae dicti Domini Regis, per eundem
Magistrum Johannem and Guidonem Palms servientem ad Legem, Johannem Grueleye
Attornatum dicti Domini Regis, Johannem Port Solicitatorem causarum ejusdem
Domini Regis, and Antonium Babyngton Generosum, de and super ultima voluntate
Edwardi Stafford nuper Comitis Wiltshyre, concernente Manerium suum de Drayton
in Comitatu Northamptoniae, ac omnia alia terras and tenementa sua in feodo
simplici existentia.
RObert Merbury Esquyer, of the age of sixty one years, or more, sworn and
examyned the day and year aboveseid, seith and deposes on his oath, that he
was servaunt to Edward Stafford, late Earl of Wiltshyre, in the rome of
Gentilman-usher of his Chamber, by the space of twenty five years or more,
which was at the time of the decese of the seid Earl. Also he seith, that the
seid Earl, about such time that he should ride towerd Blackhethe Feld, had
caused a Deed to be made of his seid Manor of Drayton, to the use of my Lady
his Wife, for term of her life; forsomuche the seid Earl in the morning when
he should depart towerd the seid Feld, being in the Chapel Chamber, this
Deponent being present, called his seid Lady to him, deliveryng the seid Deed
to her: Whereupon she then looked and kest it from her unto the floor, saying,
that she would not say gramercy therefore, except she should have Warmester,
and then she, as she seid, would thank him therefore. Whereupon this Deponent,
at the commandment of the seid Earl, took up the seid Deed, and delivered it
to the seid Earl, which Earl then broke the Seall from it, and did cast it
out of the window into the Moote there, saying to his seid Lady, that such a
person should have it of his gift, which he trusted should yeve to him a better
gramercy for it than she did; which Earl then departed into the great Chamber,
and called this Deponent to him, commaundyng and chargyng this Deponent, as he
should answer before God to testifye, bear witness, and openly declare, if
ought then good should come to the said Earl at the seid Feld, that his full
mind and last Will was, and should be, that his Cossyn Earl of Shrewsbury should
have to him and to his heirs for ever, the seid Manor of Drayton, and all his
other Fee simple Lands, after his detts were paid and his Will performed. And
so the said Earl departed, then taking his horse, towerd the seid Feld, at
which time this Deponent rode with him a certain space of the way. Whereupon
at such time that this Deponent should take his leave of the seid Earl, he
seid to this Deponent, Robert, forget not to bear witness of that thing
whereof I spoke to thee in the great Chamber concerning my Manoir of Drayton
and all my other Fee simple Lands; to whom this Deponent answeryng seid, that
he would remember his Commandment, and so departed from the seid Earl,
returnyng to Drayton foreseid, to wait upon the foreseid Lady according to the
commandment of the seid Earl. And he seith, that immediately after the
comeynge of the seid Earl from Blackhethe Feld to Drayton foreseid, and
as soon as his Boots were drawn of, he called to him this Deponent, demanding
of this Deponent whether he remembered the words which the seid Earl spoke to
him before that time in the seid great Chamber, when he was going toward
Blackhethe Feld, concerning Drayton and his other Fee simple Lands. Whereunto
this Deponent answeryng seid, that he remembered them well, desireyng the seid
Earl to know, wheder it were his pleasure to contynewe still in the same mind
or nay. Which Earl then seid, that he contynewed in that mind, and so would
do while he lyved, charging this Deponent to bear witness thereof, whatsoever
soden aventur or chance should happen or come to the seid Earl. Also this
Deponent seith, that after the seid words spoken he was contynewelly in
howsehold with the seid Earl duringe his life, and never knew him change his
seid mind in that behalf; forsomoche this Deponent diverse times would say to
the seid Earl, my Lord, for Gods love remember that ye put not your soul in
charge in yevynge your Lands from the heirs. Whereunto the seid Earl at all
times answered and said to this Deponent, Robert, I may as well yeve these
Lands where I will, as I may yeve the Gown of my back; For as for the heirs
of Veere, they shall never inherit them. Also this Deponent seith, that at
such time that the seid Earl was sick, this Deponent contynewelly abode with
him, by which seasson this Deponent never knew the seid Earl change his mind
in this behalf. And this Deponent also seith, that on Pahne-Sunday eve, which
was the eve of our Lady-daye of the Annuntiation, and also which was the day
next before the decesse of the seid Earl, this Deponent asked of the seid Earl
whether he had made his Will or nay, which Earl then seid, that he had made
noon as yet, but that he would do. And that this Deponent asked how his
Lordship was minded with Drayton and with all his Fee simple Lands, whereof he
commanded this Deponent before that time to bear witness; which Earl then
seid, that it was oon of the greatest causes why he would change his Will, for
as his mind had been to his Cossen Earl of Shrewsbury, so should it contynewe
for ever; commanding this Deponent and other there present to testifye, that
his last Will was and should be, that his Cossen George Earl of Shrewsbury
should have his Manoir of Drayton and all other his Fee simple Lands to him
and to his heirs for ever, after the detts paid and the Will of the seid Earl
performed. Then present at the speaking of the seid words William Pemberton
yet lyving, and diverse others decessed. Whereupon the seid Earl went to other
cogitations, at what time noe man thought that the seid Earl should have
decessed so shortly as he did, but trusted that the seid Earl should have lyved
much longer than he did; albeit on the morrow about ten of the clock, what
time the Priest was at Mass and reding of the Passion, the sed Earl departed
to Gods mercy without any chaungyng of his Will or mind concerning the
premises, as far as this Deponent knew or understood. But this Deponent
seith, that about seven of the Clock in the morning of the seid Palme-Sunday
John Mordaunt Serjeaunt at Law came to the seid Earl, and asked him how he did;
which Earl then seid, well as it pleases God; and then the seid Mordaunt
departed again from thence. And about ten of the Clock then next followyng the
seid Mordaunt came again to the seid Earl with a Will made in the name of the
seid Earl, which Will the seid Mordaunt then red to the seid Earl when he was
anoyled and in extreme peynes of death, so that the seid Earl neither herd nor
understode what the said Mordaunt red, wherein as by the seid redyng it
appeared to this Deponent, that nether the Manoir of Drayton, nether any part
of the Fee simple Lands of the seid Earl were expressed in the seid Will. And
after the seid redyng of the seid Will the seid Earl was deed, or a man
perfetly might seye a Pater Noster and Ave Maria and oon Creed. And more he
knows not.

Deposition of William Pemberton.
WIlliam Pemberton Gentilman, of the age of forty years or more, sworn and
examined seith, that he was brought up of a chyeld with Edward Stafford late
Earl of Wiltshyre, and in his servyse, as sum time his kerver, and sum times
lay in bed with the seid Earl when it pleased him, by the space of twenty years
and more, which was to the time of his decesse, Also he seith, that many and
diverse times the seid Earl showed and reported to this Deponent, that noon of
the chylderen or heirs of Vere should inheret his Manoir of Drayton, or any
part of his other Fee simple Lands, but that his Cossen the Earl of
Shrewsbury should have to him and to his heirs for ever the seid Manoir, with
all his other Fee simple Lands, all his detts paid and his Will performed. Also
this Deponent seith, that the day next before the decesse of the seid Earl, the
seid Earl rehearsed the seid words before this Deponent, Robert Merbury and
others now decessed, wyllinge and charging them to bear witness whenever
ever they should be called, that his full myend and last Will was and should be,
that his Cossyn George Earl of Shrewsbury should have his Manoir of Drayton with
all his other Fee simple Lands, to him and to his heirs for ever, after his
detts paid and his Will performed. And he seith, in virtue of his oath, and as
he shall answer before God, he was continewelly present with the seid Earl
from the seid time of the foreseid speking of the seid words by the seid Earl
unto that the seid Earl was deed, about ten of the Clock before noon on
Palm-Sondaye, and which was our Lady day Annuntiation, about which time the
Priest being at Mass, was redyng of the Passion, by all which seasson this
Deponent never knew, herd, or understoode that the seid Earl changed his will
or myend either in word or deed in that behalf. And more he knows not.

Deposition of Henry Caine.
HEnry Caine Yoman, of the age of eight and forty years and more, sworn and
examyned seith, that he was Grome of the Chamber to the seid Earl by the space
of seven years; and after that this Deponent was Yoman of the Chamber with the
seid Earl by the space of other seven years and more, which was to the time of
the decesse of the seid Earl, by which seasson after Blackhethe Feld as well
at Drayton as at Palenall and diverse other places, this Deponent diverse and
meny times has herd the seid Earl openly declare, for his will, before this
Deponent and diverse others of his fellows both Yomen and Gromes of the
Chamber, that his Cossyn Earl of Shrewsbury should have to him and to his heirs
for ever the Manoir of Drayton and other his Fee simple Lands, after his Detts
paid and his Will performed, commaundnig this Deponent and other his fellows
to record and testifye the premysses. Also this Deponent seith, that the seid
Earl about a month before his decesse gave lycense to this Deponent to go to
Newark upon Trent for such besinesses as this Deponent there had to do, about
which seasson this Deponent came to the Earl of Shrewsbury, lyeing at Wynfeld,
at whose coming the seid Earl demanded of this Deponent, how his Cossyn Earl
of Wiltshyre did; Whereunto this Deponent aunswering seid, that at his
departing from the seid Earl of Wiltshyre he was metely in good health: which
Earl of Shrewsbury then seid, that the understode that the seid Earl of
Wiltshyre should be decessed. And then this Deponent seid, that he would ride
streyht to his seid Lords place to know the certente, and to bring ready word
again to the seid Earl of Shrewsbury. Whereupon at the coming of this Deponent
to Drayton his seid Lord was deed and buried, and diverse of his fellows, both
Yomen and Gromes of the Chamber, now decessed, without asking of any question
by this Deponent, seid to him, that their Lord and Master had yeven and
bequethed to the Earl of Shrewsbury and to his heirs for ever his Manoir of
Drayton with all his other Fee simple Lands, after his Detts paid and his Will
performed: And that the seid Earl of Wiltshyre had required the seid Earl of
Shrewesbury to be good Lord and Master to them, as he trusted verelye he would
be. Whereupon this Deponent took his Horse and returned to Wynfeld foresaid,
where this Deponent showed to the seid Earl of Shrewsbury, how the seid Earl of
Wilteshyre had bequeathed and wylled to him Drayton with other his Fee simple
Lands, in manner and form as he has above deposed. And more he cannot depose.

Deposition of William Boys.
WIlliam Boys Yoman, of the age of eight and forty years and more, sworn and
examyned seith, that he was Servant to the seid Earl of Wilteshyre as being
Usher of his Hall, and keeper of his Park at Drayton, by the space of twenty
years and more, which was to the time of his decesse. Also this Deponent
seith, that the seid Earl about two days before he leyd him down of the
sycknesse whereof he dyed, walked into his Park of Drayton and seid to this
Deponent, that his mind and last Will was and should be, that his Cossyn Earl
of Shrewsbury should have his Manoir of Drayton, with all his other Lands in
Fee simple, to have to hyme and to his Heirs for ever, after his Detts paid
and his Will performyd; which words this Deponent, as he seith, has herd the
seid Earl speak above forty times, commandynge this Deponent to beer witness
thereof; sayeing also, that he would have his seid Cossyn Shrewsbury to socor
and help this Deponent and other his feloes, if theye should need of Mastershyp
or Lordshyp, and so he woold require his seid Cossyn so to do. Also he
seith, that he never knew or herd that the seid Earl any time changed his seid
mind and Will in any poyent thereof, but that he ever contynewed in the same
mind during his life: And more he knows not.

Deposition of Chrystopher Myddylton.
CHrystopher Myddylton, of the age of forty five years and above, sworn and
examyned, seith in virtue of his oath, that he was Grome of the styrop to the
Earl of Wilteshyre by the space of six years or more, which was to the time of
his decesse. Also he seith, thet he herd the seid Earl, as well in taking his
journeye towerd Blackhethe feeld as after his returning from thence at
Drayton, Bakenall and in other places, dyvers times report and seye, that
noone of the heirs of Veer should inherit his Manoir of Drayton or any other
his Fee-simple Lands, though he should be drawn in Hell: But that his last
Will was and ever should be, that his Cossyn Earl of Shrewsbury should have the
seid Manoir, and all his Fee simple Lands, to him and to his heirs for ever,
after his Detts paid and his Will performed, which he woold yeve to his seid
Cossyn for a remembrance, trustyng he woold be good Lord to his Servauntes;
which Earl to the knowledge or understandyng of this Deponent never changed his
seid Will or myend in that behalf. Also he seith that about a wyke or more
after the burying of the seid Earl, Thomas Mountegue, one of the Feoffees and
Executors of the seid Earl, came to this Deponent at a place in Drayton called
the Bareheed, demanding of this Deponent how he woold do; whereunto this
Deponent aunswering seid, that he knew not how to do, nether whether to goo
as yeat; which Mountegue then seid, that he thought that William Merbury his
old Master woold have this Deponent; this Deponent seid, that Master Mordaunt
Serjaunt had desired his Servys, and had offered to him good wages, but he had
not agreyed to take them, nor knew not whether he so woold. And which
Mountegue then seid to this Deponent, thou know that I am oon of the
Feoffees in my Lords Lands, and also oon of his Executors, and knew as much
of his myend as sum other did, and yeat I am not called to Council, for
there is now in the tower here in the place at Drayton Master Mordaunt
Serjaunt, Sir Thomas Cheneye, William Merbury and other such as plesyth them,
which will not let me be pryveye what they do there: But what they do or
intend to do I cannot tell, or whether they will change my Lords Will in any
thing; But this I know of troth, that our Lord and Master's myend was at the
time of his death, that his Cossyn Earl of Shrewsbury should have this Manoir
here of Drayton, and all other his Fee simple Lands, after his Detts paid and
his Will performyd. And then this Deponent seid to the seid Mountegue, that he
dyverse times has herd his seid Lord sey and report the same. And more he
knows not.

Deposition of Thomas Cade.
THomas Cade Clarke, Parson of Buckworth in the Diocese of Lincoln, of the age
of forty eight years and more, sworn and examyned the first day of the Month
of March, in the fifth year of the Reign of King Henry the Eight, upon the
testament and last will of Edward late Earl of Wiltes seith and deposes, that
he knew well and perfetly the seid Earl, insomoche this Deponent was his
household Chaplayne by the space of seven years and more. And as concerning the
making of the Testament and last Will of the seid Earl, this Deponent seith,
that he can nothing depose of the contents thereof, but affirms, the twenty
fourth day of March, then being Palm-Sonday, in the year of our Lord God one
thousand four hundred ninety and eight, this Deponent was present at the Manoir
of Drayton the day and year aboveseid in a high Chamber, in which Chamber the
seid Earl lay sick, and there in the presence of this Deponent the seid
Testament and last Will was engrosed in Parchment by one Philip Foster, and
presented and delyvered unto the Hands of the seid Earl, and then and there in
presence of this Deponent the seid Testament and last Will was so sealed with
his accustomed square Signet, graved with a ramping Bear upon a Berewerdes
Staff, then being present at the sealing of the seid Testament and last Will
John Mordaunt Serjeaunt at the Law, Robert Wittelbury, William Marbury, Philip
Foster, James Walbef, Master William Hylde then Master of the College of
Foderinghay, this Deponent, and others more, whose names he perfetly remembers
not. Also this Deponent affirms, that the seid Testament and last Will of the
seid Earl so Sealed was his last Will and Testament, and that he never made
after that time any other Testament, neither solemn in writing, nor
nuncupative by word, and that he renounced all other Wylls, and took him only
to that Will, and would the same to stand for his last Will and Testament and
none other; seying also, that the seid Earl was at the time of the sealing of
the seid Testament and last Will in perfect mind and good remembrance. And at
the same time the seid Earl delivered the seid Testament and last Will so
perfitly engrosed and sealed, unto the hands of William Merbury, one of the
seid Earls Executours, in the name of all other his Executours. This done as
above is written, the seid Earl prayed and required this Deponent, that he would
housell him, and thereunto this Deponent answered and seid these words
following; My Lord, I have made every thing in full redynesse to go to Mass,
if ye be so pleased, and at the same Mass to consecrate an hooste, and when
Mass is done, to housell you. Nay seid the same Earl, I pray you let me not
tarry so long. And thereupon this Deponent went down into the Chapel, and
brought the Sacrament up to the seid Earls lodging Chamber, and set it upon the
cupborde there ready prepared for the same, and came to the same Earl lyeing in
his bed, and seid to him these words following; My Lord, I have brought to you
your Maker and Redeemer, as ye have desired me to do; and forasmoche as every
Priest that shall take upon him to minester the same Sacrament to any Christen
man, ought to examine the faith of soche person as it shall be minstred unto, I
do require of you that I may know what faith is in you, and how ye believe.
Whereunto the seid Earl answered and seid, I believe in Almighty God Creator
and Maker of Hevyn and Earth, and in Jesus Christ his only begoten Son; and
so in effect he answered fourth to all the twelve Articles of the Faith, with
many other good and contryte words; and seid these words following to this
Deponent and to all other then being present there, I pray you witness with me
(and looked on side to th'oder, folks being in the Chamber) and all you. And
after these words the seid Earl with contrite heart made a general knowledge
to God, seying, Confiteor Deo, beatae Mariae, etc. Then this Deponent, by such
authorite as to him was yeven, unto the seid Earl granted and gave absolution;
and that done, the seid Earl received the Sacrament by the hands of this
Deponent with great reverence and meekness of heart. And after that the seid
Earl commanded this Deponent to go to Mass in the seid Earls Chamber, where
at that time the seid Earl lay; and for because the seid Chamber was sumewhat
close, the seid Earl commanded certain panes of the window of the seid Chamber
to be taken down, and to th'entente that more fresh air should coume in,
commanded that the window should be set open, in which window this Deponent
then seid Mass; and for because there came so much wind in at the seid
window, this Deponent spoke to Philip Foster to help him at that time to sing,
that when he should come to the consecration of the host, that then the seid
Philip should shut the said window, and so to remain shut till this Deponent
had used. And when this Deponent had begun his Mass, the seid Earl of his own
mind perceiving that the wind was noyense to this Deponent in seying his
Mass, commanded the seid window to be shut, before he came to the Epistle in
the seid Mass. And after Mass ended, there went a Chaplain of the seid Earls
to high Mass in the Chapel, whose name was Sir John Bukmaster, and at the
passion time of the seid high Mass so seid in the seid Chapel by the seid Sir
John Bukmaster, there came to this Deponent one of the seid Earls Servaunts
called Robert Wilkinson, and seid to this Deponent these words following;
Fader, for the reverence of God come to my Lord, for he is in the pains of
death. And thereupon this Deponent departed out of the seid Chapel into the
seid Earls Chamber, and found there noe creature but himself only. And this
Deponent lighted a fise of wax that was hallowed, and seid these words
following, In manus tuas, Domine, etc. And in that same moment the seid Earl
departed to God out of this present life. And thus this Deponent left the deed
body of the seid Earl, whose soul God absolve. And more he knows not.

Deposition of James Walbef.
JAmes Walbef of Osneye in the County of Oxford Gentleman, of the age of fifty
years, sworn and examined upon the Testament and last Will of Edward late Earl
of Wiltes seith, that he was Auditor to Edward late Earl of Wilts, whose soul
Jesus pardon. And this Deponent seith, that he was present at the Manoir of
Drayton on Palme-Sonday in the morning, the fourteenth year of the Reign of
our late Sovereigne Lord King Henry the seventh, in the Chamber where the seid
Earl lay sick on his dethbed, at which time the seid Earls last Will was
brought forth by one Philip Foster, sometime being Schole-master and Servaunt
to the seid Earl. At which time John Mordaunt then Sarjeaunt at the Law there
being present, after the seid Will was read, demanded and asked of the seid
Earl, whether that his full mind was, that that Will should clearly stand for
his last Will or not, and if he would renounce all manner of other Wylls.
Whereunto the seid Earl answered and seid, that he did renownce all other
Wylls, and that he would hold him to that Testament only, and that it should
stand to be ferme and stable for his last Will and Testament and none other,
with an articule which the seid Earl caused to be put into the end of his
Will, that Robert Wilkinson should have an annuitie of forty shillings for term
of his life, and also the seid Earl recyted certain articules of his Will in
especial as hereafter follows, that is to sey, that the seid Philip Foster
should have an annuitie of four marks for term of his life, as this Deponent
remembers, and also that Edward Bruet then Grome of his Chamber should have an
annuitie of forty shillings for term of his life, and that all Fees which
were granted by Deed or by Patent by his Fader, his Mother or his Graundfader
Green or by himself, should be held ferme and stable for term of their lyyes
to whom they were granted. And after this done the seid Will was sealed with
a Sygnet of Gold, the print whereof was a Bear, as this Deponent remembereth,
the which Sygnet was in his powche under his bedes head at that time. And
after it was sealed, the seid Earl delivered it to the hands of William
Marbury Esquier, one of his Executours, in the presence of diverse of his
household Servaunts. And after the seid Will was so red, sealed and delivered
to the seid William Marbury, the seid Earl desired to be howselled, and then
and there one Sir Thomas Cade, then Chaplain to the seid Earl, went into the
Chapel, and brought forth an host, which was consecrate before that time,
to the seid Earl, and thereupon the seid Sir Thomas Cade had many good words of
exhortation to the seid Earl before he was howselled for his souls health, and
the seid Earl had in likewise many good words to him and to them that stood by,
like a good true Christian man, which this Deponent now persetly remembers
not; And thereupon the seid Earl was howselled by the hands of the seid Sir
Thomas Cade. And after that the seid Earl commanded the seid Sir Thomas Cade
to go to Mass. Whereupon the seid Sir Thomas Cade went to Mass in a window
before the seid Earl; and about the space of an hour after the seid Mass was
done, there went another Priest to high Mass in the Chapel, and at the
passion time of the seid high Mass the seid Earl departed out of this world.
And this Deponent seith, that he was servaunt to the seid Earl many years, and
was privye to the orderinge of diverse and many matters touching the seid Earl.
Also this Deponent seith, That the Will of the seide Earl was written in Paper
and corrected by the seid Earls Council, before it was written into Parchment;
and after that it was so corrected by the seid Council and by the
commandment of the seid Earl, the seid Earl commanded William Marbury to
cause his seid Will to be written and engrossed into Parchement, and thereupon
the seid Will was so written by the hands of the seid Philip Foster as is
above deposed. And this Deponent seith; that he was never privye any time
before the death of the seid Earl at the making of the seid Will, or otherwise,
nether herd, knew nor understoode by the seid Earl at any seasson, that his
Cossyn Earl of Shrewsbury should have the Manoir of Drayton or any other Lands
or Tenements of the seid Earls; but as this Deponent remembers, the seid Earl
made his seid Cossyn Earl of Shrewsbury Overseer of his last Will and
Testament. Also this Deponent seith, that he was daily in the House of the seid
Earl from Crystmasse unto the day of his death in keeping of his audite, and
declared all the declarations upon the Thursday before the day of his decese,
and that he never herd any other Will by mouth or otherwise rehearsed for his
full Will, other then the seid Will. And more this Deponent knows not in this
matter as he seith.

Inquisitio capta post mortem Edwardi Comitis Wilts, etc.
INquisito Indentata capta apud....... in Comitatu praedicto....... die.....
Anno Regni Regis Henrici Octavi post Conquestum quinto, coram Richardo Pulter
Escaetore dicti Domini Regis in Comitatu praedicto, virtute officii sui, tam
post mortem Edwardi nuper Comitis Wilts, quam post mortem Elizabethae nuper
uxoris Thomae Cheney Militis and Constanciae nuper uxoris Johannis Parre,
necnon Annae nuper uxoris Humfridi Brown, per sacramentum, etc. Qui dicunt
super Sacramentum suum, quod Richardus Bollesore Clericus, Willielmus de Ashele
Clericus, Nicolaus Green and Nicolaus Thenford fuerunt seisiti de Manerio de
Drayton cum pertinentiis; Et sic inde seisiti, Licentia Regia inde primitus
obtenta, dederunt Manerium illud cum pertinentiis Henrico Green, filio Henrici
Green, and haeredibus de corpore ipsius Henrici filii exeuntibus; virtute
cujus doni idem Henricus filius fuit inde seisitus in feodo talliato, and obiit
de tali statu inde seisitus. Et dicunt insuper Juratores praedicti, quod
Henricus Green fuit seisitus de Luffwyck cum pertinentiis, ac de advocatione
Ecclesiae de Luffwyck in Dominico suo ut de feodo; Et sic inde seisitus, dedit
Manerium praedictum ac advocationem Ecclesiae praedictae cum eorum pertinentiis
Henrico Green filio suo, and haeredibus de corpore suo exeuntibus; virtute
cujus doni idem Henricus filius fuit inde seisitus in Dominico suo and de feodo
talliato per formam doni praedicti, and obiit de tali statu inde seisitus. Post
cujus mortem Maneria praedicta cum pertinentiis, simul cum advocatione ejusdem
Ecclesiae de Luffwyk, descendebant cuidam Constanciae nuper Comitissae Wilts,
ut Consanguineae and haeredi ipsius Henrici filii, videlicet ut filiae Henrici
Green, filii Johannis, filii ipsius Henrici filii; Virtute cujus eadem
Constancia fuit inde seisita in feodo talliato per formam doni praedicti, and
obiit de tali statu inde seisita. Post cujus mortem Maneria praedicta simul cum
advocatione ejusdem Ecclesiae de Luffwyck descendebant cuidam Edwardo nuper
Comiti Wilts, ut filio and haeredi ipsius Constanciae; Virtute cujus idem
Edwardus Comes fuit inde seisitus in Dominico suo ut de feodo talliato per
formam doni praedicti; Et sic inde seisitus de praedicto Manerio de Drayton cum
pertinentiis, licentia Regia inde primitus obtenta, feoffavit Thomam Mountegu
and Willielmum Pemberton, Habendo eis in feodo ad usum ipsius Comitis and
haeredum suorum ex part praedictae Constanciae, Matris ipsius Comitis, and ad
inde perimplendam ultimam voluntatem ejusdem Comitis; Et de praedicto Manerio
de Luffwyck feoffavit dictum Thomam Mountegue and alios, Habendo eis in feodo
ad usum ipsius Comitis and haeredum suorum ex part praedictae Constanciae
matris ipsius Comitis, Et ad inde perimplendam ultimam voluntatem ejusdem
Comitis. Et idem Comes per ultimam voluntatem suam voluit quod idem Thomas
Mountegue and alii Executores ejusdem nuper Comitis, perciperent exitus and
proficua dictorum Maneriorum de Drayton and Luffwyck cum pertinentiis, ad
perimplendam ultimam voluntatem dicti nuper Comitis. Et postea idem Comes obiit
sine exitu de corpore suo procreato; post cujus mortem usus Maneriorum
praedictorum, simul cum advocatione ejusdem Ecclesiae de Luffwyck, cum eorum
pertinentiis, descendebant praefatae Elizabethae Cheyne nuper uxori Thomae
Cheyne Militis, Elizabethae nunc uxori Johannis Mordaunt, Annae nuper uxori
Humfridi Brown, praedictae Constanciae nuper uxori Johannis Parre, and
Etheldredae Veer, ut Consanguineis and haeredibus ipsius Edwardi nuper Comitis
ex part praedictae Constanciae, matris dicti nuper Comitis, videlicet
praefatae Elizabethae Cheyne ut filiae and haeredi Margeriae, unius sororum and
haeredum praedicti Henrici Green patris praedictae Constanciae nuper
Comitissae, matris praedicti Edwardi nuper Comitis, Et praedictis Elizabethae
Mordaunt, Annae, Constanciae nuper uxori Johannis Parre, and Etheldredae Veer,
ut filiabus and haeredibus Henrici Veer de magna Adyngton in dicto Comitatu
Northamptoniae Armigeri, filii and haeredis Isabellae, alterius sororum and
haeredum praedicti Henrici Green Patris praedictae Constanciae nuper
Comitissae, matris praedicti Edwardi nuper Comitis. Et dicunt insuper Juratores
praedicti quod praedicta Elizabetha, nuper uxor dicti Thomae Cheyne Militis,
obiit tertio die Aprilis, Anno Regni Henrici nuper Regis Angliae septimi decimo
septimo, sine exitu de corpore suo exeunte; post cujus mortem medietas omnium
maneriorum praedictorum, advocationum and caeterorum praemissorum, cum eorum
pertinentiis, descendebant praefatis Elizabethae uxori Johannis Mordaunt,
Annae, Constanciae uxori Johannis Parre, and Etheldredae ut Consanguineis and
haeredibus dictae Elizabethae Cheyne, videlicet ut filiabus and haeredibus
dicti Henrici, filii Isabellae, sororis dictae Margeriae, matris dictae
Elizabethae Cheyne. Et dicunt Juratores praedicti, quod dicta Constancia nuper
uxor dicti Johannis Parre obiit...... die Augusti, Anno Regni dicti Domini
Henrici nuper Regis Angliae Septimi decimo septimo, sine exitu de corpore suo
exeunte; post cujus mortem quarta pars praedictorum Maneriorum, advocationis ac
caeterorum praemissorum cum pertinentiis, descendebant praefatis Elizabethae
Mordaunt, Annae and Etheldredae, ut sororibus and haeredibus ipsius Constanciae
Parre. Et dicunt ulterius Juratores praedicti, quod dicta Anna cepit in vitum
Humphridum Brown, and habuerunt exitum Georgium Brown; Et quod dicta Anna
postea obiit, videlicet decimo quinto die Septembris, Anno Regni dicti Domini
Henrici nuper Regis Angliae Septimi vicesimo secundo; Et quod idem Georgius
Brown est aetatis sex annorum and amplius. Et dicunt Juratores praedicti, quod
praedictum Manerium de Drayton cum pertinentiis tenetur de Domino Rege in
Capite, per quae servitia juratores praedicti penitus ignorant; Et quod
Willielmus Merbury exitus and proficua ejusdem Manerii a tempore mortis dicti
Edwardi nuper Comitis, usque primum diem Octobris, Anno Regni Domini Henrici
dicti nuper Regis Angliae Septimi vicesimo octavo, percepit and habuit; Et quod
Robertus Merbury a dicto primo die Octobris usque ad diem hujus Inquisitionis
percepit and habuit. Et ulterius dicunt quod praedictum Manerium de Luffwyck,
cum advocatione ejusdem Ecclesiae de Luffwyck cum eorum pertinentiis, tenetur
de Abbate de Peterburgh per fidelitatem, and per quae alia servitia Juratores
praedicti penitus ignorant; Et quod dictus Willielmus Merbury exitus and
proficua ejusdem Manerii a tempore mortis dicti Edwardi nuper Comitis usque
dictum primum diem Octobris dicto Anno vicesimo octavo, percepit and habuit; Et
quod Robertus Wittelbury a dicto primo die Octobris usque primum diem Maii,
Anno Regni Domini Regis nunc primo, exitus and proficua ejusdem Manerii
percepit and habuit; Et quod....... Clement and...... uxor ejus exitus and
proficua a dicto primo die Maii usque diem hujus Inquisitionis perceperunt and
habuerunt. Et dicunt Juratores praedicti, quod praedicta Ecclesia de Luffwyck
vacavit circa decimum octavum diem Octobris Anno Regni Domini Henrici nuper
Regis Angliae vicesimo quarto; Et quod Johannes Mordaunt ad eandem Ecclesiam
praesentavit Willielmum Hamswayte Capellanum, qui ad suam praesentationem fuit
admissus, institutus and inductus. In cujus, etc.

Et postea praedictus Johannes Mordaunt and Elizabetha uxor ejus, Georgius
Brown, Johannes Brown and Etheldreda uxor ejus prosecuti fuerunt breve de
forma donationis in distender versus Thomam Mountegue and Willielmum Pemberton
de Manerio de Drayton cum pertinentiis in Comitatu praedicto, and continuatur
processus quousque praedicti Johannes Mordaunt, Elizabetha uxor ejus, Georgius
Brown, and Johannes Brown and Etheldreda uxor ejus recuperaverunt Manerium
praedictum cum pertinentiis versus praedictum Thomam Mountegue and Willielmum
Pemberton, prout pro termino Trinitatis Anno octavo Henrici Octavi apparet.
Virtute cujus recuperationis ipsi Johannes Mordaunt and Johannes Brown
intraverunt in Manerium praedictum cum pertinentiis. Et alias praedicti
Johannes Mordaunt and Elizabetha uxor ejus, Georgius Brown, Johannes Brown
and Etheldreda uxor ejus prosecuti fuerunt breve de forma donationis in
distender versus Thomam Mountegue de Manerio de Luffwyck cum pertinentiis in
Comitatu praedicto, and continuatur processu quousque praedicti Johannes
Mordaunt, Elizabetha uxor ejus, Georgius Brown, and Johannes Brown, and
Etheldreda uxor ejus recuperaverunt Manerium praedictum cum pertinentiis versus
praedictum Thomam Mountegue, prout pro termino Sanctae Trinitatis Anno octavo
Regis octavi apparet. Virtute cujus quidem recuperationis praedicti Johannes
Mordaunt and Johannes Brown intraverunt Manerium praedictum cum pertinentiis.

An Award between the Earl of Shrewsbury, and John Mordaunt concerning the
Manor of Drayton.
TO all Christian people, to whom this present writing Indented shall come,
hear, or see, Robert Brudenell and Richard Elliot, two of the Kings Justices,
send greeting in our Lord.
Whereas there have been diverse variances and debates, moved and had, between
the Right Honorable Lord George Earl of Shrewsbury on the one party, and John
Mordaunt Squire and Elizabeth his Wife, one of the Cossyns and heirs to the
Right Honorable Edward late Earl of Wiltshire on his Mothers side, that is to
say, by Constance Mother of the said Earl and Daughter and heir of Henry Green
of Drayton in the County of Northampton Squire, and Humphrey Brown Squire,
late Husband to Amye, and George Brown his Son and heir apparent, and Son and
heir to the same Amye, another Cossyn, and another of the heirs to the said
Earl of Wilshire after the form aforesaid, and Sir Wistan Brown Knight, and
John Brown his Son and heir apparent, and Audrey his Wife, the third Cossyn
and heir to the same Earl after the manner abovesaid on the other party, of and
upon the right, title, reversion and possession as well to the aforesaid Manor
of Drayton with the appurtenances, as of all other Manors, Lands, Tenements,
and Hereditaments with their appurtenances, in the said County of Northampton,
or elsewhere, which late were to the said Constance, or to the foresaid Henry
Green, or to any other person or persons, to the use of them or the other of
them; which Manors, Lands, Tenements, the foresaid Earl of Shrewsbury claims
by a Will, supposed to be made by the said Earl of Wiltshire, by which Will the
foresaid Earl of Wiltshire should Will to the said Earl of Shrewsbury, all his
Feesimple Land; Whereupon the foresaid parties have compromitted themselves, to
abide the Award, Ordinance and Judgment, of us the said Robert Brudenell and
Richard Elliot Arbitrators indifferently named and chosen by and between the
aforesaid parties, to award, ordain, and deem, as well of and upon the
premises, as for and upon all manner Evidences, Charters, Escripts, Writings
and Aminiments concerning the premises, or any part of them, and of all manner
of Actions, Suits, Quarrels, and Demands, had or moved between the foresaid
parties, or other Servants, or Friends before the date of these presents,
concerning the premises. And we the aforesaid Arbitrators taking upon us the
authority and power to Award, Ordain and Deem, of and upon the premises,
calling before us the Counsels of the said parties, hearing and seeing their
Tytels, Answers, Replications, Evidences, Proves, and all other their
Allegances, concerning their aforesaid Tytles and Interess, by good
deliberation and by consent of the said parties, Award, Ordain and Deem, of and
upon the premises, in manner and form following, that is to say, forasmuch as
the aforesaid John Mordaunt, Sir Wistan, Humphrey Brown, George and John
Brown, have showed to us the said Arbitrators, a Will supposed to be made by
the same Earl of Wiltshire, and sealed with his Seal; in which Will he revoked
all former Wills, and willed that same Will to stand in his full strength and
virtue, and for his last Will; and in that Will there is no clause whereby the
said Earl of Shrewsbury should have any of his Manors, Lands, or Tenements, as
by the same more plainly appears. And also they have showed unto us fair and
sufficient Deeds, and other Writings, proving the foresaid Manor of Drayton,
and other the said Manors, Lands, Tenements and hereditaments, to be yeven in
tail to the Ancestors of the said Constance, Mother to the said Earl of
Wiltshire, and that the same Earl of Wiltshire had and enjoyed the same by
reason of the same tails, and the foresaid Elizabeth and George Brown, and
Audrey, be Cosens and next heirs to the said Constance, Mother to the said
Earl of Wiltshire, and to the said Earl on his said Mothers side, and heritable
to the foresaid Manors, and other premises, by reason of the same tails:
Wherefore we Award, Ordain and Deem, that the foresaid Elizabeth, George Brown
and Audrey, shall have and enjoy all the foresaid Manors, Lands, Tenements and
Hereditaments, and other the premises, to them and to their heirs, according to
the foresaid Titles of Inheritance, and that the foresaid Earl of Shrewsbury
shall by his several Deeds sufficient in the Law, to be enrolled, release to
the said John Mordaunt and Elizabeth, Humphrey Brown, George Brown, and John
Brown and Audrey his Wife, and to such person or persons as they shall name,
to the use of the said Elizabeth, George and Audrey, and their heirs, all such
Right, Title, Claim, Interest and Demands, as the said Earl of Shrewsbury, or
any person or persons to his use, has in the foresaid Manors, Lands and
Tenements, and other the premises, by reason of any Gift or Will in the
premises, or any part of them, made by the foresaid Earl of Wiltshire to the
foresaid Earl of Shrewsbury, at the Costs and Charges of the said John
Mordaunt, John and George Brown in all things; And furthermore the said Earl
of Shrewsbury shall deliver, or cause to be delivered to the said John
Mordaunt, Humphrey Brown, John and George Brown, or to their Deputy or
Deputies in London, all such Charters, Evidences and Writings, as he to his own
use, or any other to his use, to his knowledge, has only concerning the
premises, as soon as it may be conveniently done; for the which Releases and
other things above specified, and for other Costs and Charges which the
aforesaid Earl of Shrewsbury has had by occasion of the premises, We the said
Arbitrators, Award, Ordain, and Deem, that the said Sir Wistan, John Mordaunt,
Humphrey Brown and John Brown shall content and pay to the said Earl of
Shrewsbury, his Executors or Assigns, two hundred Marks of lawful Money, in
form following; that is to say, the said John Mordaunt shall content and pay
to the foresaid Earl of Shrewsbury, his Executors or Assigns, in the day of the
Feast of St. George the Martyr, next coming after the date above written, at
the Rode of the North door in the Cathedral Church of Paul's in the City of
London, between the hours of Nine and Eleven of the Clock of the same day, a
hundred marks; and the foresaid Sir Wistan, Humphrey Brown and John Brown
shall content and pay to the foresaid Earl, his Executors or Assigns, in the
day of the Feast of St. Andrew the Apostle then next ensueing, at the said Rode
in the said Church, between the hours of Nine and Eleven of the same day, a
hundred marks, residue of the foresaid two hundred marks. Also we Award,
Ordain, and Deem, that the said John Mordaunt, Sir Wistan Brown, Humphrey and
John Brown by their Deed and Deeds, as sufficient as the said Earl of
Shrewsbury by his Council shall advise, shall release to the said Earl of
Shrewsbury, and as many persons as the said Earl shall name and appoint, in
writing before the Feast of St. Michaell the Archangel next coming after the
date hereof, which has done, labored or spoken for the said Earl in his
foresaid cause, all actions of Trespasses, Debates and Demands personal, had,
or done before the date of these presents, at the Costs and Charges of the said
Earl of Shrewsbury and the said Earl and all the foresaid persons, which have
done, spoken, or labored any thing for the said Earl of Shrewsbury, in or for
his trial or possession of the premises or any part of them, shall be for ever
discharged against the same Sir Wistan, John Mordaunt and Elizabeth his Wife,
Humphrey Brown, George Brown, John Brown and Audrey his Wife, and every of
them, of all Actions, Trespasses, and Demands personal, which they have, or
might have, against the same Earl or the foresaid other persons, for any cause
had or done touching the premises before the date of these presents.

In witness whereof the foresaid Arbitrators to every part of these Indentures
of their Award, have put to their Seals this twentieth day of March, the sixth
year of the Reign of King Henry the Eight.
A Release from the Earl of Shrewsbury to John Mordaunt of all his Right
concerning the Manor of Drayton.
OMnibus Christi fidelibus ad quos praesens Scriptum pervenerit, nos Georgius
Comes Salopiae
salutem in Domino sempiternam.
Sciatis, nos praefatum Georgium Comitem remisisse, relaxasse, and omnino pro
nobis and haeredibus nostris quietum clamasse, Johanni Mordaunt and Elizabethae
uxori ejus, uni consanguinearum and haeredum Edwardi nuper Comitis Wilts, ex
part matris ejusdem Edwardi, videlicet filii Constanciae, filiae and haeredis
Henrici Green nuper de Drayton in Comitatu Northamptoniae Armigeri, Humfrido
Brown, Georgio Brown, filio and haeredi apparenti dicti Humfridi Brown; and
filio and haeredi Amiae alterius consanguinearum and haeredum dicti Edwardi, ex
part dictae Constanciae, Johanni Brown and Etheldredae uxori ejus tertiae
consanguinearum and haeredum dicti Edwardi, ex part dictae Constanciae, Thomae
Montegue and Willielmo Pemberton, haeredibus and assignatis suis, ad usum
eorundem Johannis Mordaunt and Elizabethae uxoris ejus, Humfridi Brown,
Georgii Brown, and Johannis Brown and Etheldredae uxoris ejus, and haeredum
ipsarum Elizabethae, Georgii and Etheldredae, totum Jus nostrum, statum,
titulum, clameum, interesse and demandum quae habemus, seu unquam habuimus, de
and in Manerio de Drayton, ac de and in omnibus aliis maneriis, terris,
tenementis, reditibus, reversionibus, Boscis, pratis, pascuis, pasturis and
aliis haereditamentis quibuscunque, cum eorum pertinentiis, quae nuper fuerunt
praedictae Constanciae, aut praedicti Henrici, sive alicujus alterius, sive
